STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 21, 2022
TaSeanda Johnson
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
RE: License #: CP820201497
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/06/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-7087.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201497
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS - Western
Facility Address: 27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Facility Telephone #: (313) 934-8910
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1992
Service Types:
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 9/28/2022, 9/29/2022, 10/4/2022, 10/06/2022

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Four of 28 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• In one record where an employee was promoted to
supervisor, the employee’s six-month’s evaluation to his
current role, due by 5/14/2022, was completed late on
8/18/2022.
• A second employee record did not show documentation
of a 2021 annual evaluation for the employee. One was
documented for 1/2/2020 and 9/1/2022.
• Two other employee records showed the employee’s
2021 annual evaluation due by 8/30/2021 was completed
on 6/17/2022 and 8/30/2022 respectively.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
3

R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
(c):
In two of seven initial service plans reviewed the plan did not
show documentation of (c).
Repeat Violation-Renewal.
(h):
One of seven initial services plans reviewed did not show
documentation of (h).
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.33 5(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Timeliness of Updated
Plans (Commitment 69)
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
Four of 24 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 12/28/2021-3/26/2022 updated service plan
(USP)did not contain a treatment plan signed by the birth
parents.
• A second child’s 8/23/2021-9/21/2021 initial service
plan(ISP), and 12/16/2021-3/15/2022 and 3/16/022-
4

6/13/2022 USP did not contain a treatment plan signed
by the birth parents.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance, as required by the standard:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 6/11/2022-9/9/2022 USP or 8/1/2022
placement change.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the child’s 9/3/2021-10/1/2021 ISP. One was
completed outside the required timeframe on 8/15/2022
and or 8/26/2022. An FTM was also not documented for
this child’s 6/25/2022-9/22/2022 USP.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 3/31/2022-6/28/2022 or 6/29/2022-
9/26/2022 USP. One was completed outside the required
timeframe on 7/27/2022 related to the latter USP.
• A fourth child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 8/23/2021-9/22/2021 ISP or next two
USPs. One was completed on 4/6/2022, that was
outside the required timeframe for the USP reporting
5

periods.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021; Interim 2020.
FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Two of 24 services plans reviewed were approved one day and
two days late respectively.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Seven of 24 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 5/12/2022-6/10/2022 ISP treatment plan was
not signed by the caregiver.
• A second child’s 9/3/2021-10/1/2021 ISP treatment plan
was not signed by the caregiver until 1/19/2022. This
child’s 12/28/2021-3/26/2022 USP treatment plan was
not signed by caregiver until 5/18/2022. Additionally, this
child’s 3/27/2022-6/24/2022 USP treatment plan was not
signed by the caregiver until 9/22/22.
• A third child’s 5/16/2022-6/10/2022 ISP treatment plan
was signed by the caregiver but not dated. It could not
be discerned if the treatment plan was signed timely.
• A fourth child’s 9/22/2021-12/15/2021 USP treatment
plan was not signed by the birth parent until 3/2/2022.
• A fifth child’s 4/19/2022-5/18/2022 ISP treatment plan
was not signed by youth, caregiver and birth parent until
8/4/2022.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021-cited under FOM-722-8C
and Interim 2020, cited under R400.12418(5).
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
6

MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
• Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
• Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure
One of four closed foster child records and two of eight open
foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• The closed child’s record showed the DHS-69 for the
child’s 3/23/2022 case closure was completed late on
6/27/2022.
• One of the two open child’s records showed the child
experienced six placement changes (6/8/2022; 7/6/2022,
7/18/2022, 7/27/2022, 7/28/2922, and 8/1/2022) and the
DHS-69 for each respective replacement was completed
late on 9/29/2022.
• The second of the two open child’s records showed the
child had nine placement changes (between 8/26/2021
and 3/21/2022) and a DHS-69 was not documented for
the child’s 3/21/2022 placement change.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to the
child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the youth is age
18 or older or has been legally emancipated, at the time of
closure:
• A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain a
copy in the case record).
• The child's social security card. Note: In cases where the
social security number has been verified and
documented per policy, the caseworker must make
efforts to obtain a social security card.
• Any available education records.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation the parent was provided a copy of the child’s
birth certificate, social security card or medical passport.
7

FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One child’s records did not show documentation that the
medical passport was provided to a caregiver at one of
the child’s replacements.
• A second and third child’s record did not show
documentation of a quarterly medical passport due
December 2021 for one child and July 2022 for the other
child.
• A fourth child’s record did not show documentation that
the medical passport was provided to the caregiver at
the child’s initial placement.
• A fifth child’s record did not show documentation that a
medical passport was provided to the three separate
foster homes/caregivers the child was replaced to on
8/25/2021, 8/28/2021 and 10/22/2021 respectively.
Repeat Violation -Renewal 2021-cited under MISEP 6.49.
FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of
Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal. The screening
instrument must be completed by a person who knows the child
8

best, before the child's Early Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic,
and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child exam.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a trauma
screening.
• A second and third record showed the respective child’s
trauma screening was due by 10/3/2021 and 6/11/2022;
and both were completed after, more than 30 days after
the child’s date of placement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12405(3) (e) & (f) Change of placement:
• The agency was apprised it shall clearly and consistently document the date the
parent and guardian ad litem were notified of the change, as well as how
preparation occurred for the child irrespective of the child’s age or mental
capacity.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
9

to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2021 Renewal inspection where it
received the following violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) -Personal records.
• R400.12212(2)(f) -Personnel records.
• R400.12413(1)(c)(ii)-Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2) ((a) &(b)- Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(c) & (h) -Initial service plans.
• R400.12420(1)(g)- Updated service plans.
• ISEP 6.33 -Assessments and service plans (Commitment 69).
• ISEP 6.49- Medical passport (Commitment 85).
• FOM 722-6B- Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-6H- Documentation of contacts.
• FOM 722-08C- Foster care-parent agency treatment plan & service
agreement.
• FOM 722-8E - Foster care/juvenile justice action summary.
The agency completed tracking spreadsheets, email reminders related to
performance evaluations and 5-day package reviews from children protective
services, as well as daily report reminders to workers. Additionally, the agency
completed and implemented ISP/USP checklist reviews for the workers’ and
supervisors’ completion/ reviews of these reports; and completed trainings related to
the renewal corrective action plan and ongoing expectations. The agency provided or
showed me various documents related to these items/tools. Various workers and
managerial staff reported these efforts have proven helpful.
The agency made progress gains in some areas but was not totally successful with
compliance with of all aspects of the corrective action plan. It received repeat
violations, as indicated in this report.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
One safety alert was received for the agency on 9/7/2022.
Concern:
The smoke detectors in the home on the second floor and in the bedroom where two
children reside was not working properly. It was beeping during the visit. The foster
parent was aware of the need to fix the smoke detector.
Resolution:
On 9/9/2022 the worker verified that the smoke detectors in the caregiver’s home were
working.
10

Concern:
Chemical products including bleach and floor cleaner were on the kitchen floor where
they could be reached by the small children placed in the home. The caregiver was
informed and asked to move the products. Please make sure this was completed.
Resolution:
On 9/9/2022 the worker verified that the chemical supplies had been put away.
Concern:
The children were not included on the initial chart and were not home at the time of the
visit. Please verify their well-being. It appears to be a borrowed bed situation (North
Central is the responsible agency.)
Resolution:
On 9/9/2022 the worker saw, and verified, the well-being of the two North Central foster
youths.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 9/28/2022 was received. Areas reviewed as a
part of that report related to the citations listed earlier in this report; and progress on the
corrective action plan related to it.
Interviews
The chief administrator and managerial staff participated in the entrance and exit
conferences. A review and discussion around the agency’s last inspection’s corrective
action plan, staff and policy changes since that last inspection, and the agency’s review
of its current status/program functioning were the focus of the entrance conference. The
DCWL Analyst was in attendance at the entrance conference via telephone. She
shared information related to the foster parent and unlicensed relative home visits, and
the safety alert. Three foster care staff, and one supervisor were interviewed during this
inspection.
Rule and policy violations found this inspection were the focus of the exit conference.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
11

October 19, 2022
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 21, 2022
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
